meanings.def: to send out air from the mouth
examples: + adv./prep. You're not blowing hard enough!
The policeman asked me to blow into the breathalyser.
blow something + adv./prep. He drew on his cigarette and blew out a stream of smoke.

meanings.def: when the wind or a current of air blows, it is moving; when it blows, the wind is blowing
examples: The birds were singing and a warm wind was blowing.
+ adv./prep. A cold wind blew from the east.
It was blowing hard.
It was blowing a gale (= there was a strong wind).
The wind blew the door shut.
Both candidates wore blue jeans.
They chose an intense blue for the walls.

meanings.def: to be moved by the wind, somebody’s breath, etc.; to move something in this way
examples: + adv./prep. My hat blew off.
+ adj. The door blew open.
blow somebody/something + adv./prep. I was almost blown over by the wind.
She blew the dust off the book.
The ship was blown onto the rocks.
The bomb blast blew two passers-by across the street.
blow something + adj. The wind blew the door shut.

meanings.def: if you blow a whistle, musical instrument, etc. or if a whistle, etc. blows, you produce a sound by blowing into the whistle, etc.
examples: the sound of trumpets blowing
blow something The referee blew his whistle.

meanings.def: to clear your nose by blowing strongly through it into a tissue or handkerchief
examples: She grabbed a tissue and loudly blew her nose.

meanings.def: to kiss your hand and then pretend to blow the kiss towards somebody
to make or shape something by blowing
examples: to blow smoke rings
to blow bubbles (= for example, by blowing onto a thin layer of water mixed with soap)
to blow glass (= to send a current of air into melted glass to shape it)

meanings.def: if a fuse blows or you blow a fuse, the electricity stops flowing suddenly because the fuse (= a thin wire) has melted because the current was too strong
to break open or apart, especially because of pressure from inside; to make a tyre break in this way
examples: The car spun out of control when a tyre blew.
The truck blew a tyre and lurched off the road.

meanings.def: to break something open with explosives
examples: The safe had been blown by the thieves.

meanings.def: to make known something that was secret
examples: One mistake could blow your cover (= make your real name, job, intentions, etc. known).
We’re going to blow his operation wide open.

meanings.def: to spend or waste a lot of money on something
examples: He inherited over a million dollars and blew it all on drink and gambling.

meanings.def: to waste an opportunity
examples: She blew her chances by arriving late for the interview.
You had your chance and you blew it.

meanings.def: used to show that you are annoyed, surprised or do not care about something
examples: Blow it! We've missed the bus.
Well, blow me down! I never thought I'd see you again.
I'm blowed if I'm going to (= I certainly will not) let him treat you like that.
Let's take a taxi and blow (= never mind) the expense.

meanings.def: to leave a place suddenly
examples: Let's blow this joint.

meanings.def: to kill yourself/somebody by shooting yourself/them in the head
examples: He put a gun to his head and threatened to blow his brains out.
While cleaning his shotgun he had accidentally blown his own brains out.

meanings.def: to vomit
to help somebody have a fresh, lively state of mind again
examples: A brisk walk should blow the cobwebs away.

meanings.def: to get very angry
to tell something secret, especially by mistake
to change your opinion about something often
to produce a very strong feeling of pleasure or shock
examples: Wait till you hear this. It'll blow your mind.
a collection of photographs that will blow your mind

meanings.def: to get rid of your energy, anger or strong emotions by doing something active or noisy
examples: I went for a long walk to let off steam.
I like blowing off steam and I like saying things that shock people.

meanings.def: to destroy somebody/something completely
to show that somebody/something is not good by being very much better than it/them
examples: I like my old phone, but this new model blows it out of the water.

meanings.def: to praise your own abilities and achievements
to try to trick somebody or lie to somebody, particularly by saying something is better than it really is
to surprise or impress somebody very much
used by somebody who does not want to do something because it involves too much effort
examples: Sod that for a lark! I'm not doing any more tonight.

meanings.def: to use bombs or other weapons to destroy somebody/something completely
examples: The plane was blown to pieces when the bomb exploded.

meanings.def: to completely destroy somebody/something with an explosion
examples: The truck was blown to kingdom come.

meanings.def: to get very angry
if a plan, etc. blows up in your face, it goes badly wrong in a way that causes you damage or makes you feel embarrassed
to tell somebody in authority about something wrong or illegal that somebody is doing
no problem is so bad that it does not bring some advantage to somebody
to tell people unpleasant facts about something
examples: Her article lifts the lid on bullying in the workplace.

meanings.def: to breathe quickly and loudly through your mouth after physical effort
examples: Eventually, puffing and blowing, he arrived at the gate.

meanings.def: to get an idea of what is likely to happen before deciding what to do

idioms.def: to kill yourself/somebody by shooting yourself/them in the head
examples: He put a gun to his head and threatened to blow his brains out.
While cleaning his shotgun he had accidentally blown his own brains out.

idioms.def: to vomit
to help somebody have a fresh, lively state of mind again
examples: A brisk walk should blow the cobwebs away.

idioms.def: to get very angry
to tell something secret, especially by mistake
to change your opinion about something often
to produce a very strong feeling of pleasure or shock
examples: Wait till you hear this. It'll blow your mind.
a collection of photographs that will blow your mind

idioms.def: to get rid of your energy, anger or strong emotions by doing something active or noisy
examples: I went for a long walk to let off steam.
I like blowing off steam and I like saying things that shock people.

idioms.idiom: blow somebody/something out of the water
idioms.def: to destroy somebody/something completely
examples: I like my old phone, but this new model blows it out of the water.

idioms.def: to praise your own abilities and achievements
to try to trick somebody or lie to somebody, particularly by saying something is better than it really is
to surprise or impress somebody very much
used by somebody who does not want to do something because it involves too much effort
examples: Sod that for a lark! I'm not doing any more tonight.

idioms.def: to use bombs or other weapons to destroy somebody/something completely
examples: The plane was blown to pieces when the bomb exploded.

idioms.def: to completely destroy somebody/something with an explosion
examples: The truck was blown to kingdom come.

idioms.def: to get very angry
if a plan, etc. blows up in your face, it goes badly wrong in a way that causes you damage or makes you feel embarrassed
to tell somebody in authority about something wrong or illegal that somebody is doing

idioms.idiom: it’s an ill wind (that blows nobody any good)
idioms.def: no problem is so bad that it does not bring some advantage to somebody

idioms.idiom: lift the lid on something | take/blow the lid off something
idioms.def: to tell people unpleasant facts about something
examples: Her article lifts the lid on bullying in the workplace.

idioms.def: to breathe quickly and loudly through your mouth after physical effort
examples: Eventually, puffing and blowing, he arrived at the gate.

idioms.idiom: see which way the wind is blowing
idioms.def: to get an idea of what is likely to happen before deciding what to do

meanings.def: a hard hit with the hand, a weapon, etc.
examples: She received a severe blow on the head.
He was knocked out by a single blow to the head.
The two men were exchanging blows.
He landed a blow on Hill's nose.
He felt a stinging blow across the side of his face.
It was the gardener who delivered the fatal blow.
Jack caught him a glancing blow on the jaw.
The blow knocked him to the ground.
The force of the blow knocked him out.
He rained heavy blows on the old woman.
The man went down in a hail of blows.
two blows of the axe

meanings.def: a sudden event that hurts or damages somebody/something, causing the people affected to be sad or disappointed
examples: Losing his job came as a terrible blow to him.
It was a shattering blow to her pride.
The new cuts will be seen as a crippling blow for people on low incomes.
The recent bomb attacks are a serious blow for the peace process.
The blow came at a meeting on Saturday.
The news came as a bitter blow to the staff.
a mortal blow to British industry
Can you stay with Cathy tonight? She's had a bit of a blow.

meanings.def: the action of blowing
examples: Give your nose a good blow (= clear it completely).
Try to put the candles out in one blow.
I’ll give three blows on the whistle as a signal.

meanings.def: a description of an event that gives you all the details in the order in which they happen
examples: He insisted on giving us a blow-by-blow account of what had happened.

meanings.def: to start fighting because of something
examples: We almost came to blows over what colour the new carpet should be.
The children came to blows over the new toy.

meanings.def: to shock somebody/something very much; to be very harmful to somebody/something
examples: Her sudden death dealt a blow to the whole country.

meanings.def: to hit somebody/something
to make something that is unpleasant seem less unpleasant and easier to accept
examples: I should try to soften the blow of this news.
The chancellor may try to soften the blow somewhat with a cut in interest rates.

meanings.def: to do something in support of/against a belief, principle, etc.
examples: He felt that they had struck a blow for democracy.

idioms.idiom: a blow-by-blow account, description, etc. (of something)
idioms.def: a description of an event that gives you all the details in the order in which they happen
examples: He insisted on giving us a blow-by-blow account of what had happened.

idioms.def: to start fighting because of something
examples: We almost came to blows over what colour the new carpet should be.
The children came to blows over the new toy.

idioms.idiom: deal somebody/something a blow | deal a blow to somebody/something
idioms.def: to shock somebody/something very much; to be very harmful to somebody/something
examples: Her sudden death dealt a blow to the whole country.

idioms.def: to make something that is unpleasant seem less unpleasant and easier to accept
examples: I should try to soften the blow of this news.
The chancellor may try to soften the blow somewhat with a cut in interest rates.

idioms.def: to do something in support of/against a belief, principle, etc.
examples: He felt that they had struck a blow for democracy.

meanings.def: used to show that you are annoyed about something
examples: Blow! I completely forgot it.
